channel.title: Building a cheap gaming PC
channel.description:
Hey guys,
My goal is to build a very cheap gaming PC that can handle most games pretty well. This is what I have so far:
[b]CPU:[/b] [url=http://pcpartpicker.com/part/amd-cpu-fd6300wmhkbox]AMD FX-6300 3.5GHz 6-Core Processor[/url] ($109.99 @ Amazon)
[b]Motherboard:[/b] [url=http://pcpartpicker.com/part/gigabyte-motherboard-ga78lmtusb3]Gigabyte GA-78LMT-USB3 Micro ATX AM3+ Motherboard[/url] ($44.99 @ Micro Center)
[b]Memory:[/b] [url=http://pcpartpicker.com/part/team-memory-ted38g1600hc1101]Team Elite 8GB (1 x 8GB) DDR3-1600 Memory[/url] ($59.99 @ Newegg)
[b]Storage:[/b] [url=http://pcpartpicker.com/part/western-digital-internal-hard-drive-wd10ezex]Western Digital Caviar Blue 1TB 3.5" 7200RPM Internal Hard Drive[/url] ($57.98 @ OutletPC)
[b]Video Card:[/b] [url=http://pcpartpicker.com/part/evga-video-card-02gp43751kr]EVGA GeForce GTX 750 Ti 2GB Video Card[/url] ($149.99 @ NCIX US)
[b]Case:[/b] [url=http://pcpartpicker.com/part/xion-case-xon560bk]Xion XON-560 MicroATX Mini Tower Case[/url] ($29.99 @ Newegg)
[b]Power Supply:[/b] [url=http://pcpartpicker.com/part/corsair-power-supply-cx430]Corsair Builder 430W 80+ Bronze Certified ATX Power Supply[/url] ($19.99 @ Micro Center)
[b]Optical Drive:[/b] [url=http://pcpartpicker.com/part/asus-optical-drive-drw24b1stblkbas]Asus DRW-24B1ST/BLK/B/AS DVD/CD Writer[/url] ($19.99 @ Micro Center)
[b]Total:[/b] $492.91
It seems pretty solid to me for under $500 (after MIR's, etc).
Anyone have any other suggestions?
Thanks

item.title: Building a cheap gaming PC
item.dc:creator: @tigerclan tigerclan
item.description:
@tigerclan wrote:

[quote=“Muroth, post:20, topic:541278”][quote author=tigerclan link=topic=660151.msg4414658#msg4414658 date=1395281227]

I have a fx 6300 paired with a gtx 650 ti and 6 gb of ram and it plays every thing ive thrown at it on max settings. great budget build

Awesome!

Wouldn’t get your hopes up… even my overclocked GTX 680 struggles with max on some games, you must be playing at a low resolution or something…

What? if 1080p is low resolution then okay… I guess it is moving to 1440p
[/quote]

He probably thinks you would be running 800x600 instead of 1080x1080[/quote]

I run 1920 x 1080 on my games

Read full topic

item.title: Building a cheap gaming PC
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“Jc22493, post:17, topic:541278”][quote author=SilentCJ link=topic=660151.msg4414562#msg4414562 date=1395252782]

I have a fx 6300 paired with a gtx 650 ti and 6 gb of ram and it plays every thing ive thrown at it on max settings. great budget build

Awesome!

Wouldn’t get your hopes up… even my overclocked GTX 680 struggles with max on some games, you must be playing at a low resolution or something…
[/quote]

That’s no problem. I don’t plan on ultra-ing every game haha. I’m not even much of a gamer, I figured that building a budget gaming PC would be optimal for everyday use even if I didn’t game as opposed to the other way around (building a PC for homework, videos etc, then wanting to game on it).[/quote]
Yeah definitely agree, better to have a ‘do it all’ PC mine’s basically turning into a data center, as well as a render slave and gaming machine

Read full topic

item.title: Building a cheap gaming PC
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:16, topic:541278”][quote author=Jc22493 link=topic=660151.msg4414545#msg4414545 date=1395244057]

I have a fx 6300 paired with a gtx 650 ti and 6 gb of ram and it plays every thing ive thrown at it on max settings. great budget build

Awesome!
[/quote]
Wouldn’t get your hopes up… even my overclocked GTX 680 struggles with max on some games, you must be playing at a low resolution or something…[/quote]

That’s no problem. I don’t plan on ultra-ing every game haha. I’m not even much of a gamer, I figured that building a budget gaming PC would be optimal for everyday use even if I didn’t game as opposed to the other way around (building a PC for homework, videos etc, then wanting to game on it).

Read full topic

item.title: Building a cheap gaming PC
item.dc:creator: @Muroth Muroth
item.description:
@Muroth wrote:

What’re you doing for cooling the cpu? Stock will do for now but if you plan on running intense applications maybe think about an aftermarket cooler and good thermal paste

Read full topic

item.title: Building a cheap gaming PC
item.dc:creator: @vortex vortex
item.description:
@vortex wrote:

you might want to read reviews of different 750 tis because for example the evga one has the fan(s) locked at 40% or something iirc, which may not be a good thing

Read full topic

item.title: Building a cheap gaming PC
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“Jc22493, post:7, topic:541278”]Yeah, I just read about it yesterday. Thanks!

Probably gonna go with 1x8 and 1x2.

I’m just not sure how this PC will run with games on ultra settings.[/quote]
See benchmarks: http://www.bit-tech.net/hardware/graphics/2014/02/18/nvidia-geforce-gtx-750-ti-review/5

By that statement I hope you don’t mean one 8gb module and one 2gb module? If so I advise against it, better off sticking with a single 8gb module and upgrading to 16gb (2x8gb) if needed in the future. In that sense it would be better than a 2x4gb combination, besides, the difference is very minimal believe me.

Also, do you really need an internal DVD drive? I bought an external USB drive 2 years ago for £15 and have never needed an internal one since, and it can used across multiple computers… obviously

Read full topic

item.title: Building a cheap gaming PC
item.dc:creator: @Muroth Muroth
item.description:
@Muroth wrote:

Ram and processor are more than enough. Video card is pretty good, It really just depends on the game really. I only have 1gb but smooth gameplay for many on high

Read full topic

item.title: Building a cheap gaming PC
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

Yeah, I just read about it yesterday. Thanks!

Probably gonna go with 1x8 and 1x2.

I’m just not sure how this PC will run with games on ultra settings.

Read full topic

item.title: Building a cheap gaming PC
item.dc:creator: @Muroth Muroth
item.description:
@Muroth wrote:

Yeah what eyeownyew said, I also debated when building my gaming rig. For an extra $5 it’s worth getting the 2 4GB sticks. I use 2x4GB DDR3 1333Mhz and have no lag what-so-ever.

Read full topic

item.title: Building a cheap gaming PC
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

"2 X 4gb can be used in dual channel mode which is better. Dual channel doubles the communication between the memory controller and RAM, thus increasing system performance."
Wish I had known this

Read full topic

item.title: Building a cheap gaming PC
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

Muroth:

It’s better to get two 4gb x2 sticks I read. Great build otherwise.

Thanks!

And why is 2x4 > 1x8?

Read full topic

item.title: Building a cheap gaming PC
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

Hey guys,

My goal is to build a very cheap gaming PC that can handle most games pretty well. This is what I have so far:

CPU: AMD FX-6300 3.5GHz 6-Core Processor ($109.99 @ Amazon)

Motherboard: Gigabyte GA-78LMT-USB3 Micro ATX AM3+ Motherboard ($44.99 @ Micro Center)

Memory: Team Elite 8GB (1 x 8GB) DDR3-1600 Memory ($59.99 @ Newegg)

Storage: Western Digital Caviar Blue 1TB 3.5" 7200RPM Internal Hard Drive ($57.98 @ OutletPC)

Video Card: EVGA GeForce GTX 750 Ti 2GB Video Card ($149.99 @ NCIX US)

Case: Xion XON-560 MicroATX Mini Tower Case ($29.99 @ Newegg)

Power Supply: Corsair Builder 430W 80+ Bronze Certified ATX Power Supply ($19.99 @ Micro Center)

Optical Drive: Asus DRW-24B1ST/BLK/B/AS DVD/CD Writer ($19.99 @ Micro Center)

Total: $492.91

It seems pretty solid to me for under $500 (after MIR’s, etc).

Anyone have any other suggestions?

Thanks

Read full topic
